text:
Hurricane Idalia is making its 
way toward Florida's Gulf Coast.

And a 20-year-old Ugandan man could 
face the death penalty after being
charged with so-called "aggravated homosexuality."

Good morning. I'm Windsor Johnston, with 
NPR News, and here are today's top stories:

The Biden administration has released a list of 
medications that will be subject to the first

ever price negotiations by Medicare. 
The list includes 10 prescriptions,

including blood thinners Eliquis and Xarelto, 
and the diabetes drug Jardiance. The provision

that allows Medicare to negotiate the price of 
prescription drugs for people over the age of 65

was part of President Biden's signature Inflation 
Reduction Act that he signed into law last year.

Hurricane Idalia is gaining strength 
as it heads toward the Gulf Coast of

Florida. NPR's Greg Allen reports the storm 
is expected to make landfall tomorrow as a

category 3 hurricane with wind 
speeds of 120 miles per hour:

"The National Hurricane Center says Idalia 
is moving north through the Gulf of Mexico

on a track that's likely to bring it ashore 
Wednesday in Florida's Big Bend area. That's

a relatively undeveloped part of the state, 
but Florida Governor Ron DeSantis says people

should be prepared for impacts along most of 
the Gulf Coast, from Tampa Bay to Panama City:

'This thing comes in at category three, it's going 
to knock over trees, it's going to knock over

power lines, it's going to cause an interruption 
in service, so just be prepared for that.'

"Idalia is also forecast to bring a storm 
surge as high as 12 feet in some areas

and flooding from heavy rains as it moves 
through Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas.
"Greg Allen, NPR News, St. Petersburg."

Former White House Chief of Staff 
Mark Meadows testified in Atlanta

yesterday as part of an effort to 
move racketeering charges against

him to federal court. Georgia Public 
Broadcasting's Stephen Fowler has more:

"Meadows is one of 19 people, 
including the former president,

under indictment for allegedly violating 
Georgia laws by taking various steps to

overturn the 2020 election there. In a court 
hearing seeking to move his charges to federal

jurisdiction and ultimately seek to dismiss 
them, Meadows defended actions like organizing

a call between Trump and Georgia's Secretary 
of State. He argued that, as Chief of Staff,

those things were part of his job responsibilities 
advising the president, but prosecutors alleged

Meadows engaged in political activity outside 
of his role and violated state law in the

process. The move comes as arraignments for 
all 19 defendants is set for next Wednesday.
"For NPR News, I'm Stephen Fowler, in Atlanta."

A 20-year-old man in Uganda has been charged 
for so-called "aggravated homosexuality."

NPR's Emmanuel Akinwotu reports it's an 
offense that carries the death penalty:

"We managed to get in touch 
with his lawyer, Justine Ballia,

and she said he's the first person to be charged 
for 'aggravated homosexuality.' She told us he's

being charged for having, 'sexual contact 
with someone with a disability of the same

sex.' We don't know what the disability 
is or really much else about the case."
NPR's Emmanuel Akinwotu reporting.
This is NPR.
